Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Hurricane Harvey, natural disasters, and willingness to help over time

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Greater willingness to help is an important source of assistance to victims of natural disasters such as hurricanes. Such willingness may translate into immediate desire to help (e.g., donate money) as well as the long-term propensity to support policies contributing to disaster mitigation and adaptation (at a possible cost to tax-payers). Willingness to help, however, may be a product of complex interaction between individual socioeconomic status, demographic characteristics, psychological attributes, political ideology, and beliefs about the issue of climate change. Moreover, the rally effect may be short-term for some but long-term for others. Understanding the complexity of this relationship may increase efficiency of social mobilization to help victims of natural disasters and contribute to greater environmental awareness and support for natural disaster preparedness in general. The investigator proposes to conduct a two-wave survey of public opinion on a nationally representative sample of adults in the United States. The goal of the survey is to examine respondents' reactions to hurricanes (specifically, Hurricane Harvey) and analyze how individual attitudes and willingness to help change over time.

Previously, scholars suggested investigating the time course of reactions to natural disasters but the temporal dimension of public opinion in the context of hurricanes and other such disasters remains largely unexplored. The proposed survey design examines possible deterioration of empathetic concern for victims of the disaster in the context of individual ideological preferences (e.g., liberal or conservative), partisan/political identification, psychological traits (e.g., perspective taking, social desirability bias), behavioral propensities (e.g., risk preferences, future discounting), and social environment (e.g., existence of tangible social support). An important goal of the project is to establish under which conditions helping behavior is most stable and under which it is most fragile and short-lived. Previous research has shown that willingness to help increases if responsibility for disasters could be attributed to human actions (e.g., government), not natural phenomena (which traditionally included hurricanes). Therefore, greater attribution of hurricanes to anthropogenic climate change has a potential to promote helping behavior and environmental support in general.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Natural disasters have devastating impacts on the people who are directly affected by such disasters, e.g., people of Houston affected by Hurricane Harvey in August of 2017 or people of North Carolina affected by Hurricane Florence in September of 2018. Public willingness to help is important for: (a) the immediate support for victims of natural disasters, and (b) the long-term political support of state policies designed to adapt to the impacts of future disasters. Yet according to the American Psychological Association, individual propensity to help victims of natural disasters is an understudied topic. Willingness to help may be a product of complex interaction between individual socioeconomic status, demographic characteristics, psychological attributes, political ideology, and beliefs about the issue of climate change. Moreover, the rally effect may be short-term for some but long-term for others.

A major goal of the project was to conduct and analyze a two-wave survey of public opinion on a nationally representative sample of adults in the United States. The purpose of the survey was to examine respondents reactions to hurricanes and analyze how individual attitudes and willingness to help change over time. The first wave took place in the hurricane off-season (9 months after Hurricane Harvey and 4 month before Hurricane Florence). The second wave took place immediately after Hurricane Florence (within a week). Thus, the two-wave design serves as a natural experiment since the respondents are [naturally] divided into four categories: (a) affected by Florence and other hurricanes in the past, (b) affected by Florence only, (c) affected by other hurricanes in the past but not Florence, and (d) never affected. In addition, a goal of the project was to examine responses to different kinds of media coverage: (a) neutral control, (b) coverage linking hurricanes and climate change, (c) coverage dismissing the relationship between hurricanes and climate change.

As expected, the lowest willingness to help to hurricane victims was observed for the respondents who had never been affected by hurricanes, both in wave 1 (hurricane off-season) and wave 2 (immediately after Hurricane Florence). Prior exposure was associated with a higher willingness to help, however, there was a sign of decay: Respondents affected by Florence had a higher help scale value than the respondents who were exposed to hurricanes in the past but not Florence.

Willingness to help was on average significantly lower immediately after the hurricane than during the hurricane off-season, with the exception of the respondents who were affected by Florence and no other hurricanes in the past. These results indicate that people tend to overestimate (or even exaggerate) their propensity to help when a natural disaster is an abstract, distant, and uncertain prospect. In the aftermath of a real disaster, the willingness to help drops because, we believe, the need for help is concrete and realistic.

None of the survey treatment manipulations had an effect on the respondents beliefs about climate change. Either global warming beliefs are very stable and a short educational message cannot change them, or a written statement, as opposed to a video message, is not an effective method to educate the respondents.

Among the respondents affected by Florence, the largest increase in willingness to help was observed for: (a) those who had a lower prior willingness to help, (b) those who were more altruistic, (c) those who identified as Democrats on the partisanship scale, and (d) those who believed that climate change was happening and caused by humans.

Structural equation models were used to explore direct and indirect effects of being affected by hurricanes in the past and Florence more recently. Controlling for age, education, gender, partisanship, and religiosity, we observe that, immediately after the hurricane, being affected by Florence (regardless of the past) increased individual willingness to help by about 10%, relative to those who had never been affected by hurricanes. This is a short-term (rally) effect. Being affected by hurricanes in the past, but not Florence, increased the willingness to help by about 6%. This is a long-term effect of being affected by a hurricane. This is comparable to the magnitude of the education scale variable (about 8% increase in willingness to help).

Greater willingness to help is an important source of assistance to victims of the disaster. Such willingness may translate into immediate desire to help (e.g., donate money) as well as long-term propensity to support policies contributing to disaster mitigation and adaptation (at a cost to tax-payers). The current project contributes to our understanding of the complexity underlying helping behavior. Such understanding is important for policy-makers who want to increase efficiency of social mobilization to help victims of natural disasters. This knowledge may further contribute to greater environmental awareness, support for natural disaster preparedness, and climate change mitigation in general.
